replies.text:
@HelloThere-xx1ct Your misconception is that oppression is economically sustainable. As we learned with WW2 germany, with the antebellum south, with most of those large scale dictatorships, it's not. When you can't get food for your kids, you really have nothing left to lose. Political insecurity starts to arise, and that's what leads to the downfall of dictators, the fact that they can't maintain control over their population, the fact that they can't maintain supply chains. It might not necessarily be peaceful, but it's something that's done by the will of the people, rather than the will of a separate imposing nation. Without sustained supply chains, things fall apart extremely quickly. You know, like the arab spring, the thing that actually ended up leading to the emancipation of several countries. The only exception I can think of to this is those countries which are super poor from exterior factors, like globalized trade destroying domestic economies, and fear of foreign military intervention, but I think to equate domestic oppression with foreign oppression wouldn't be accurate.
You're also ascribing to the US a set of morals, and that's questionable. Without WMDs, and with UN oversight to energy production, there's not a massive security threat, not from iraq, and thus, the US has no real self-preservation reason to invade. There's maybe a security threat from saudi arabia, but as the US has established time and again, they're willing to overlook the true saudi dictatorship responsible for 9/11 and other human rights disasters, as long as it sustains the oil lobby. The real reason is that iraq is a useful deflection from the former, and the economic benefits of war to the US are seen to be greater, or at least, acceptable. As in, war sustains the military industrial complex.

replies.author: @macdeus2601
replies.text:
@HelloThere-xx1ct No national government has an obligation to invade another sovereign nation in an effort to choose the second nation's rulers for them. That's rather absurd. 

In fact, international laws (such as the UN Charter) are rather unambiguous about Wars of Aggression and Preventative Warfare being crimes rather than obligations. 

The only thing that could have made the invasion even technically legal would have been a UN resolution to rubberstamp it as a "police action", but of course that never happened. 

Saddam Hussein was not "being allowed to reign free". His army was left in tatters in 1991, and prevented from rebuilding by a decade of extremely harsh trade embargoes that also wrecked the entire national economy and severely inhibited the rebuilding of even civilian infrastructure. American warplanes were still conducting airstrikes in Iraq on a regular basis throughout the 1990's for the sake of enforcing the ban on Iraqi military units entering the northern third of their own country due to previous atrocities there. The Kurds were pretty damn near de facto independent. 

You're engaging in pretty blatant false-dilemma fallacy if you actually mean to imply that the only possible alternative to the war as it happened was to do absolutely nothing else to prevent or inhibit any future action by the Hussein government, much less trying to pin responsibility for "all of Saddam's potential future crimes" on people who understood and were willing to acknowledge the reality that the invasion had no legitimate reason to happen and was likely to lead to catastrophe (or people who have understood and acknowledged these facts in retrospect since then). 

Come on, man. That's just silly. 

(Or perhaps risibly depraved, but I'm gonna choose to take it as a bad joke.)

replies.author: @Sarah-re7cg
replies.text: @HelloThere-xx1ct hi. I used to be an international relations major at a top university. Questions of morality and a country‚Äôs role in what to do or not do are usually easier answered in hindsight. That being said, those kinds of philosophical questions are a very, very small piece of the picture and tend to serve as a framing for justification. Think of it as a neutral tool that can turn into a weapon in the wrong hands. If you want a more accurate attempt at putting this giant puzzle together (which by the way, doesn‚Äôt look the same for every person because there‚Äôs different implicit and explicit biases we have), please consider studying political philosophy, historical contexts from different levels (local to regional) of different countries, the role of nationalism, ethnicity and identity in nation states, what a nation state even is, the spectrum of democracy and where countries land on it and why, economics, game theory, let me think what else‚Ä¶oh, post WWII political and economic structures such as the UN‚Ä¶hmm that‚Äôs all I can think of at the top of my head. Anyways, yeah a lot of interesting stuff, a lot to learn about‚Ä¶I wish it was a lot more simple but üòÖ and this is just undergrad stuff.

author: @pavarottiaardvark3431
text: Something important to note: WMD is a deliberately fuzzy political term. It's not a term embraced by generals and strategists because it covers such disparate things. The purpose of WMD as a term is to allow one to place "chemical weapons that several countries have" and "super dangerous by very rare nuclear weapons" under the same umbrella, implying that if you have one, you should be treated as having the other.

replies.author: @violeth2255
replies.text:
I'd argue that a chemical weapon that could disperse its contents over a sufficiently large area in a concentration adequate enough to remain effective could reasonably constitute a WMD due to the potential to indiscriminately harm civilian life. 

That said, mustard gas and other chemical weapons, as horrific a weapon as they are, aren't usually delivered by means that would raise them to that level (said level being comparable to a "low yield" nuclear bomb). 

I'd equally argue that most modern biological weapons, also horrible terrible things, shouldn't be raised to that level either. Nowadays, humans using biological weaponry largely tend to favor the spores or toxins that have particularly lethal outcomes for the target(s) over the infectious agent itself (for the simple reason that you don't want to accidentally have your own weapon jump over to your own forces after the next contact with the enemy). In the past, wide scale biological weaponry seems to have been depressingly common (smallpox blankets given to previously unexposed populations for example).

author: @Gutterman-tn2ry
text:
What I find especially grotesque about their justifications for the 2003 invasion of Iraq is that the goal of making Iraq a non-threat to surrounding countries had already been accomplished in Desert Storm. Iraq's military was thoroughly destroyed, with a substantial portion of its equipment lost (in particular the air defense assets and much of their armor), and Saddam was thoroughly convinced that any action against his neighbors would be met with international sanction. 

He was unable to reignite hostilities with Iran (lacking the international support which made it possible in the first place), Syria was suddenly more powerful after the losses he suffered, and Jordan was not a viable target due to geographic limitations. Kuwait and the Saudis had US military assets on standby to crush any attempt he might make with US air power as well. From the perspective of conventional war, Saddam wasn't a threat. He didn't have any actual connections to jihadi groups (or at least had fewer than our erstwhile allies in the Saudi government), and the WMD lies were absurd in numerous ways.

When he said "they had WMDs they used chemical weapons", I had to search what WMD meant, because for me it was a synonym of nukes ^^'
And what does it mean? Well, nothing precise, there's still debates about what is a WMD, but during the Cold War it was primarily used as a synonym of nukes. And after the Cold War, the term was abandonned, except to qualify the weapons that Iraq must dismantle.

Fun fact, in 2013, the FBI defined the bombs of the Boston marathon as WMD.... so apparently, if Iraq had modified a pressure cooker into a bomb, they'd have a WMD :p

replies.author: @beardedchimp
replies.text:
I marched against the war prior to invasion in Belfast 2003. I was absolutely shattered mentally. I and everyone I knew had done everything they could possibly think to voice opposition and try to stop it.

But long before the day of invasion it had become quite clear that this had absolutely nothing to do with the UN  reports or of sending in more inspectors to find the truth as a sort of justification. The UK's attorney generals  position was that it required a second UN resolution for our war to to be legal, there was absolutely no grounds on the basis of regime change.

But the inevitability was obvious, Bush and Blair displayed an absolute unified conviction. If Bush was going in, then we certainly were.

I cried for hours when "shock and awe" started, I felt the most helpless in my life. My country was illegally going to war with people on the other side of the globe, they had done nothing to hurt me and my family, or the UK in any way for that matter. I knew the vast loss of innocent lives to come, let alone the years following complete devastation of infrastructure.

I've spoken to many Iraqis since then and their stories break my heart. During occupation the absolute casual brutality of  US marines and army is hard to imagine. They utterly terrorised the local populace, proudly declaring their racism and bigotry.

There was one Iraqi who was a kid at the time. He described how the local US military base would at any time raid an entire area and demand that every single person come to the door and raise their hands as anyone hiding is considered a hostile threat.

His uncle had a disability that made navigating stairs difficult and slow. As they started the raid the uncle was sitting alone on the other side of the house. He was a child and his mum made him hide in a cupboard at the top of the stairs to protect him from these American barbarians. But he started panicking and making noise, so a US soldier shot into that cupboard door. It thankfully missed him, but it passed through into the other room and killed his uncle.

The US soldiers had absolutely no remorse and said it was entirely his own fault as they had explicitly told them to come to the door with arms raised. I cried my eyes out speaking to him, the worst thing is he blamed himself throughout adolescence since it was only because he made noise his uncle died. What an unimaginable thing to be done to a child.

Another guy mentioned how his cousin or uncle one day was driving as normal, but the US humvees as operational practice just speared across the roads and traffic pushing other cars out of the way. His relation drove through a blind intersection where one of these Humvees was coming ploughing through with him suddenly being about to crash. The Americans immediately opened fire, absolutely ravaging the car with 50cal and other rounds. They justified it on the basis that he drove with the same suspicious behaviour as a car bomber.

What really horrifies me to this day is that the US still treats these soldiers as heroes, thanking them for their service. When a single US soldier died it heralded a great ceremony on the injustice of their young hero being murdered by freedom hating terrorists. I don't remember a single time where they gave remembrance for the dead Iraqis. I never hear of stories like I recounted being told in the US, taking recognition of the routine horrific war crimes their military committed.

I haven't met any Iraqis who lived in British occupied territory like Basra, so I can't pass similar judgement on their behaviour. But one thing is for sure, the soldiers coming back to the UK weren't heralded as heroes. The Iraq war protests were the largest in all of British history, it had massive public opposition. We don't thank them for their service, they didn't make the UK safer or prevent weapons of mass destruction. They weren't the good guys delivering freedom to Iraq.

I am to the bottom of my soul sorry for what my country did to yours. I tried my best, but I always think wasn't there something more I could have done that would have stopped the madness? I'm unapologetically sorry for the trauma and death you and your family suffered. I wish whatever improbable perfect future possibility  for Iraq becomes reality.

author: @atm1947
text:
An interesting fact about Joschka Fischer‚Äôs (German foreign minister during Iraq ‚Äò03) speech mentioned in the first video: he delivered that line in English, in the presence of US Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld. That might not be super interesting on its face, but up until this point in the speech, Fischer had been speaking exclusively in German and Rumsfeld had been listening through a translator. 

Fischer purposefully spoke in English not just to address Americans in general, but Rumsfeld specifically. He wanted him to know exactly what he meant, and exactly how he felt about the war and it‚Äôs justifications. Hence why it caused a diplomatic crisis: it was a calculated and intentional comment by Joschka Fischer speaking to Rumsfeld and tangentially to America‚Äôs most jingoist politicians, stating clearly that Germany would not send its soldiers and people to die in an unjust war.

replies.author: @oremfrien
replies.text:
One of the things I never understood was why the Bush policy was a complete De-Baathification (which is what you (Noor Ahmed) were referring to when you mention "Paul Bremer decided it's a good idea to dismantle the Iraqi army, polis force and media, causing so many journalists rightly pissed off and many ex-military to be unemployed and angry over night"). De-Baathification was particularly absurd because nearly everyone who was competent and educated in Iraq was a member of the Baath Party; you simply had to be a member in order to be in any university-graduated profession or government office. 

And as you point out, firing the fourth largest military in the world and nearly every competent person is a recipe for insurgency creation. Al-Qaeda Iraq (the antecedent for Islamic State) only began achieving large-scale military victories when former generals in the Iraqi Army (who were unemployed and enraged after De-Baathification) joined al-Qaeda Iraq and directed its forces. De-Baathification directly led to the success of that particular insurgent group.

Just as a counterpoint, when the US overthrew Axis-aligned Italy in WWII, only the most senior fascists were removed, to allow the main part of Italian infrastructure to remain intact. It shows that the US knows how to remove the leadership of a government without targeting all party members and, therefore, removing all competent individuals from governance. Just for some absurd reason, that was not even considered here.

replies.author: @NoorAhmed-nk2jq
replies.text:
@oremfrien Yeah that was some strange reasoning there , you are correct about how every educated person pretty much had to be a party member, hell they had like a "supporter of the party" tier that doesn't make you a full member and that was mandatory for all high schools, I was two years away from being forced into that tier myself when the war happened, my parents were low level members as well because otherwise they wouldn't have jobs, so de-Baathification was a ridiculous and terribly misused system, a lot of doctors, university professors and scientists  lost their jobs to it, not to the same level as the military or the media, but it was still devastating and not really done with any  due process, it's not like every Baath party member had a trial or a hearing or anything,  they lost their livelihoods overnight and in some cases had a target on their backs.
Also I have to point out, the Baath isn't the Nazi party, there was nothing inherently evil about its rhetoric,  the crimes of the regime were usually done under some coverup and didn't have any type of public support so it's even more baffling they decided every single soldier or some mislead journalist  just doing their duty  deserve punishment.

replies.author: @oremfrien
replies.text: @EmperorFool I disagree. You can cause harmful consequences without intending those harmful consequences. That's why in law we have different standards (negligence, recklessness, and knowledge). In the case of using Agent Orange in Vietnam, for example, I would argue that the US military was reckless, they simply did not care that the chemical could cause defects and disorders. If there existed a chemical equally as useful as Agent Orange as a defoliant and equally expensive but did not have the hazardous side effects for humans, I find it difficult to believe that the US military would not have used the safer chemical. The US military simply did not value the lives of its servicemembers or the Vietnamese population enough to weaken its military position for those considerations. It's not that they wanted those groups to come to harm, but that they saw all of the result of use as collectively better than none of the result of use.

text: Thanks for doing this one. I have a lot of personal trauma surround the invasion of Iraq. The day after it was announced I stood up during morning assembly at my high school and said that the war was certain to go terribly, that a stable democracy couldn't be built through the barrel of a gun and that the lies told to start this war would bite us all in the ass for decades to come. I was bullied relentlessly for the next two years by not only other students, but by the faculty as well. I was called a traitor daily and told repeatedly by adults that I should be drafted, beaten or executed. The bullying only got worse as the war went badly and I had to change schools. I think a lot of the revisionism surrounding the war is related to people desperately trying to avoid feeling shame over the psychotic way they behaved towards others for years. I think a lot of people have fully melted their brains trying to avoid thinking about the behavior they engaged in after 9/11 in what has been a decades long cognitive decline brought on by fully committing to hysterical panic in the aftermath of a terror attack. replies.author: @loldoctor
replies.text:
@Bittersteel96 France also abolished slavery in particular circumstances. Revolutionary regimes were extremely precarious and constantly changing, so the legitimacy of the decision was always in question due to the questionable authority of the National Convention. More importantly, perhaps, Haiti was already in an outright revolution of its own, and abolition was more a rhetorical gesture than a profound institutional change. So it's unfair to say that Napoleon reinstated slavery, when really France had very little say in its abolition. His actions were more akin to putting down a rebellion post-hoc rather than reversing a profound governmental declaration.

Really, Haiti abolished slavery and France simply took credit. In this sense, Napoleon's reinstatement of slavery didn't go against French interests, but rather reaffirmed them.

replies.author: @furdterguson3299
replies.text:
@devonmolina5200 I don't debate the book's literary quality or even that its worth reading. And you're right, Roberts does criticize Napoleon at multiple points. But I don't think that contradicts my point. With a doorstop biography, there's inevitably going to be a mix of positive and negative actions/character traits laid out (if you go through even as critical a biography as The Power Broker, you'll find any number of complementary comments that Caro makes about Robert Moses' actions and personality). What ultimately matters is the general thrust of the book, the impression that it aims to leave the reader with. This is admittedly somewhat subjective, but it can be fairly assessed by what actions are emphasized and what actions are de-emphasized. Which facts are seen as being of ultimate importance to understanding the meaning of a historical figure and which facts aren't. I've become increasingly critical of Zinn's People's History since I first read it in high school, but he makes this point well in the introduction to the book where he analyzes a popular biography of Christopher Columbus that was published in the 60s or 70s. Zinn points out that in the Columbus book, the author doesn't lie or obfuscate when it comes to Columbus' brutal treatment of the natives; the author even uses the word "genocide". But the author emphasizes other aspects of Columbus' life and concludes "He had his faults and defects, but they were largely the defects of the qualities that made him great... There was no flaw, no dark side to the most essential of his qualities--his seamanship". 

Andrews is critical of Napoleon at various points in his book, but the central thrust is that Napoleon was a  (capital G) Great Man who should be admired. Andrews said as much many times in public speeches, including an Intelligence Squared debate I just pulled up where he said "The central point about Napoleon is the way in which he saved France." I would disagree that he saved France, but I feel like the Haitians, the victims of Napoleon's ultimately genocidal attempt to reinstate slavery, would disagree that that was the Central Point.

replies.author: @furdterguson3299
replies.text: @loldoctor I think it's fair to criticize my simplistic statement that France had abolished slavery. The actions of the slaves themselves and military necessity to a large degree forced the hand of first Sonthonax and then the National Convention. (Similar things could be said about Lincoln and the Republican congress' abolition of Slavery in the US, by the way.) But I think it would be a mistake to become too cynical about this action. If abolition was a mere grudging concession to facts on the ground, they could have limited abolition to Haiti. Instead they abolished slavery throughout the entire empire, thus emancipating hundreds of thousands of slaves in colonies where they maintained firm control. Now, was this done purely out of high-mided altruism? Of course not. This may be apocryphal, but after the vote Danton was quoted as saying something to the effect of "now the british are finished!" Along with idealism, there were larger geopolitical concerns about control in the Carribean. But the fact remains that the then-legitimate government of France abolished slavery throughout the empire. And if this had been generally seen as some wild-eyed utopian scheme carried out at gunpoint by the Jacobins, then one would think that the conservative Thermadorians who took power in 1794 and set up the Directory in 1795 would have reversed course. But the conservative republicans of the Directory did not reverse on abolition. That would not happen until Napoleon took absolute power.

author: @stephenwilliams163
text: Whew. Theres a trip down memory lane. My young opposition to the Iraq War was one of the first stepping stepping stones in my exit from the evangelical church. I remember having arguments on some of these points with other 20 somethings in the back of a church van.

replies.author: @SusCalvin
replies.text: What was the different church stances on the war?

replies.author: @stephenwilliams163
replies.text:
@SusCalvin I was involved with the Southern Baptists at the time. I can't speak to what the other denominatons were preaching, but the church I went to and the various campus ministry groups I frequented  were all strongly in favor of the war. I remember hearing sermons about how the Bush presidency was ordained by God, how the God of the old testament was not opposed to war and often commanded the ancient Israelites to wage war, and that the 6th commandment actually translated to "thou shalt not murder" instead of "kill" arguing that there was a huge difference. I remember sermons about how people who were opposed to the war were worldly and not holy.

For most of the individual Christians I knew at the time their unquestioning support for the war was similar to most of the population, only with a veneer of church created thought terminating cliches.

replies.author: @weatheranddarkness
replies.text: @stephenwilliams163 "I remember sermons about how people who were opposed to the war were worldly and not holy." reminds me of Steven Miller dismissing somebody for being "cosmopolitan". It's as though bringing any kind of context into these things is a sin all its own.

replies.author: @Leo_Zeo_Lhang
replies.text:
I know a lot of leftists, especially in America, like to criticize the military and anyone associated with it any time they get the chance but that is not a good attitude to have. Yes, the US military is used as a tool of imperialism and mainstream American culture is very militaristic, and I think this strong support for the military is why a lot of leftists try to distance themselves by overcompensating and attacking anything related to the military, but that doesn't means it's a good idea to call every veteran you see a baby killer (especially veterans who admit the US military is unjust and try to support leftist ideas). One of the big advantages the left has over the right is that we are (or at least are supposed to be) more accepting. People can change and when they do they need to find a new group that welcomes them. When veterans realize what they did was wrong and try to change and join the left they need to be brought in and educated or else they will just return to the right because they are the only group willing to accept them. 

I know the justification a lot of leftists have for rejecting veterans is that they voluntarily joined the military but I think that is vastly underestimating the amount of propaganda in American culture. I don't think manufactured consent is real consent and even if they did agree with it at the time later they may have realized their mistake, people change. I don't think everybody who has done something wrong should be permanently excluded regardless of how much they have tried to change later in their life, especially since we have all made mistakes and believed things that turned out to be wrong. In fact, people who were once on the other side are a valuable resource since they understand the other side's perspective and can help bring more people over. They were used as pawns by the politicians who pushed this war and are simultaneously perpetuators and victims of this unjust war. I think a lot of the people in this thread should talk to some leftists who used to be in the military, the subreddit r/SocialistRA and Beau of the fifth column's Youtube channel are good places to start, and remember the phrase "be hard on systems but soft on people."

text: Another great video. I just started watching the Slow Burn Podcast season about the Iraq invasion and this fits very well with that. I was working for someone in Congress on the Armed Forces Committee in late 2002 (I got to handle all the phone calls before the AUMF vote) - it was already inside knowledge that the forces were deployed in September 2002 and ready to invade. Everything that came between then and March was just advertising to sell the war, and the whole WMD "crisis" was very obviously manufactured. But the media by and large was selling what the Bush admin was providing, and it seemed like everyone had collectively lost their minds. The rest is history - can't believe that was 20 years ago.
